message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing supraventricular tachycardia, which can be treated with a Valsalva maneuver. Adenosine infusion and synchronized cardioversion are also options for treating supraventricular tachycardia, but a Valsalva maneuver can be tried first. Dipping the face in warm water is not a recommended treatment for supraventricular tachycardia.

Adenosine infusion may also be used if Valsalva maneuver is unsuccessful. Dipping his face in warm water and cardioversion are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing supraventricular tachycardia, which is a type of arrhythmia. The first line of treatment for this is the Valsalva maneuver, which can help reset the heart's rhythm. Adenosine infusion and synchronized cardioversion are other options for treating arrhythmias, but are not the first line in this case. Dipping the face in warm water is not a recognized treatment for supraventricular tachycardia.

Adenosine infusion or synchronized cardioversion may be used if the initial maneuvers are not effective. Dipping the face in warm water is not a recommended treatment for supraventricular tachycardia.
